fields.answer:
A dry-cleaning machine is similar to a combination of a domestic washing machine, and clothes dryer...it just much bigger. Garments are placed into a washing/extraction chamber (referred to as the basket, or drum), which is the core of the machine. The washing chamber can hold a number of garments which will be similar in colour and texture.

During the wash cycle, the drum is partly filled with solvent and begins to rotate, agitating the clothing. Delicate items are processed at low temperatures and reduced agitation. Once the process is complete, the drum will spin-out the solvent into a filtering and distilling chamber, and the drying process will commence on your clothes. Water is not used in the process, hence the name 'dry cleaning' . The lack of water also protects your clothes from shrinkage.
fields.question: What is dry cleaning?

fields.answer: Yes we are. We have had over 20 years of hands on cleaning, hand finishing and technical experience in the industry, so we understand clients needs and textiles. All our associate dry cleaners have been inspected and vetted to ensure they meet our high standards. Our team have owned stores in London and cleaned garments for designer fashion houses and Harrods. We do understand garment cleaning.

fields.answer: Dry cleaners and laundry specialists cannot claim to be totally Eco friendly due to the nature of utilities used and requirements to obtain best results. However, we and all our partners are looking to reduce the impact of the process on the environment. We have a variety of dry cleaning methods of which some incorporate safer chemicals which are less harmful to the environment, and our laundry processes aim to process items at the lowest possible temperature with the most soil removing effect. Laundry detergent products are mainly Bio, however please call our customer service if you have specific requests.
